channel.title: Code Optional
channel.itunes:author: Andrew Sardone, Kevin Vitale, Chris Dzombak
channel.itunes:subtitle: A podcast about the trials and tribulations of building software.
channel.itunes:summary: Three engineering comrades – Andrew Sardone, Kevin Vitale, and Chris Dzombak – talk about development, design, and shipping apps. There’s a heavy slant towards Apple tech, balanced with general inquiries around programming and the intricacies/inanities of software.
channel.description: Three engineering comrades – Andrew Sardone, Kevin Vitale, and Chris Dzombak – talk about development, design, and shipping apps. There’s a heavy slant towards Apple tech, balanced with general inquiries around programming and the intricacies/inanities of software.

item.title: 7: Our first ever guest, designing remotely
item.dc:creator: Andrew Sardone
item.description:
While Kevin takes the afternoon off for some well-deserved family and petting zoo time, we’re joined by our guest Karsten Rowe. Karsten is a UK-based designer, and together with Andrew and Chris he chats about remote work, jumping from graphic to product design, and how one grows and becomes inspired.

Note: Andrew apologizes for the episode’s poor audio quality. This is the first episode we’ve recorded in-person.

Show notes

  • Guest Karsten Rowe is the design lead at Nutshell, a simple and powerful cloud-based CRM
  • Tools for remote work
    • GitHub
    • Trello
    • HipChat
    • Copy
  • A look at some of Jony Ive’s pre-Apple work
  • Steve Jobs on crafting the world around you
  • Two James Spirits – a Detroit-based artisan distillery

Find us online

  • Andrew Sardone: @andrewa2 / andrewsardone.com
  • Kevin Vitale: @vitalekj
  • Chris Dzombak: @cdzombak / dzombak.com
  • Karsten Rowe: @karstenrowe / karstenrowe.com

item.title: 6: Unfulfilled Promises
item.dc:creator: Andrew Sardone
item.description:
Chris has an announcement, followed by a quick discussion about OS X Yosemite and iOS 8. From there, Andrew, Chris, and Kevin go back and forth on Promises and why they’re an insufficient abstraction.

Show notes

  • OS X Yosemite GM3/PB6 vs. final build
  • Continuity
  • Peer-to-peer AirPlay
  • ECMAScript Promises
  • Promises/A+
  • Lambdas
  • Callback Hell
  • Futures and promises
  • PromiseKit
  • @mxcl: PromiseKit ObjC/Swift parity
  • Bolts-iOS
  • UIAlertView+PromiseKit
  • Streams and Signals (documentation from ReactiveCocoa)
  • ReactiveCocoa
  • RxJava
  • RxJava-Android
  • bacon.js
  • RxJS
  • Andrew's CodeMash 2015 talk: Be proactive, use reactive! (⌘F “Sardone”)

Find us online

  • Andrew Sardone: @andrewa2 / andrewsardone.com
  • Kevin Vitale: @vitalekj
  • Chris Dzombak: @cdzombak / dzombak.com
item.itunes:author: Code Optional
item.itunes:subtitle: Why Promises are an insufficient abstraction.
item.itunes:summary: Chris has an announcement, followed by a quick discussion about OS X Yosemite and iOS 8. From there, Andrew, Chris, and Kevin go back and forth on Promises and why they’re an insufficient abstraction.

item.title: 4: We did talk about Core Data!
item.dc:creator: Andrew Sardone
item.description:
On this episode, Kevin throws in a big announcement, followed by a group discussion on Swift’s nil coalescing operator and the common applications of Core Data.

Show notes

  • Quick shout out to Nutshell, an awesome start-up that's building a modern cloud-based CRM
  • The “what what”, nil coalescing operator (Docs)
  • Other Swift optional sugar: Optional chaining
  • Changes in the Swift standard library for beta 5
  • CloudKit
  • Fetched Properties; Useful?
  • Kevin’s seriously singleton gist
  • Core Data
    • Apple’s Introduction to Core Data Programming Guide
    • UIKonf, Matthew Morey on High Perf CoreData
    • MagicalRecord – an ActiveRecord-style Core Data library
  • Non-Core Data
    • FMDB – the best way to use SQLite from Objective-C
    • YapDatabase – a “key/value store and MUCH MORE”
    • FCModel – An alternative to Core Data for people who like having direct SQL access.
    • Mantle – a Cocoa model framework that’s especially designed to work in tandem with an HTTP API (note, it can be used with Core Data)
  • Core Data Concurrency: Core Data Programming Guide and objc.io post
  • SOLID (object-oriented design)
    • Dependency inversion principle
    • Massive View Controllers
  • NSCoders Facebook group
  • Conflict-free replicated data types
  • Contact us
    • @andrewa2
    • @vitalekj
    • @cdzombak

media:content.media:title: 4: We did talk about Core Data!

item.itunes:author: Code Optional
item.itunes:subtitle: Kevin throws in a big announcement, followed by a group discussion on Swift’s nil coalescing operator and the common applications of Core Data.

item.title: 3: So we didn’t talk about Core Data
item.dc:creator: Chris Dzombak
item.description:
Andrew, Kevin, and Chris plan to talk about Core Data. Instead, they discuss navigation patterns for iOS apps.

Show notes

  • New Google Docs/Sheets/Slides apps
  • Path
  • 1Writer
  • WWDC Session 211, which mentions hamburger menus
  • Chris complaining about the “more” button
  • Tweetbot
  • Pocket Casts
  • Reeder
  • Swift Blog
  • Apple employees to follow on the Apple Dev Forums
  • Find us online at…
    • @andrewa2
    • @cdzombak / dzombak.com
    • @vitalekj

The Overcast UI

item.title: 2: Frameworks, you guys don’t even know how many sunshine and rainbows
item.dc:creator: Andrew Sardone
item.description:
Andrew, Chris, and Kevin sit down for a chat on “Google becoming Apple” (or so Kevin says), and how dynamic frameworks for third party developers will replace CocoaPods (or so Kevin says).

Show notes

  • Android apps on Chromebooks
  • NSHipster article mentions UIBezierPath and operator overloading
  • Swift arrays in beta 1 and 2 vs. beta 3
    • Mike Ash’s Swift features blog post and Chris Lattner’s arrays comment
  • Allowed characters in Swift operators.
  • Frameworks
    • Xcode 6’s dynamic frameworks on iOS
    • Shipping Libraries on iOS (2008)
    • Static Libraries are Really, Really Bad (2014)
  • CocoaPods
    • Upcoming CocoaPods’ dependency resolver
  • Find us online at…
    • @andrewa2
    • @cdzombak
    • @vitalekj

item.title: 1: We started this new project in Swift
item.dc:creator: Andrew Sardone
item.description:
Andrew, Chris, and Kevin sit down for their inaugural chat, scratching the surface of Swift.

Show notes

  • John Siracusa’s Copland 2010 articles
  • Cartography – the Auto layout constraint operator overloading libray mentioned by Chris
  • Noah’s ark in Swift
  • Operator overloading for FoundationKit – jednymslowem/FoundationOperators
    • We can finally get NSNumber + NSNumber!
  • Andrew has no idea what he’s doing
  • Find us online at…
    • @andrewa2
    • @cdzombak
    • @vitalekj

Permalink
